Award.AwardTitle: FUN: A finland US Network for Engagement and STEM Learning in Games

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: As part of a SAVI, researchers from the U.S. and from Finland will collaborate on investigating the relationships between engagement and learning in STEM transmedia games. The members of U.S. Team for this project come from TERC, WGBH and Northern Illinois University. The project involves two intensive, 5 day workshops to identify new measurement instruments to be integrated into each other's research and development work. The major research question is to what degree learners in the two cultures respond similarly or differently to the STEM learning games.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The FUN collaboration consisted of five parallel strands, each with separate outcomes.

 

FUN Strand 1: Games with Kinect Interactivity

EdGE and TAUCHI of Tampere designed two adaptations of EdGE’s research-grounded physics learning game, Impulse. They both used the XBOX Kinect platform. Two different interfaces (mechanics) were designed and tested with small groups in Finland and the US. The mechanics designed for Kinect showed potential for increased engagement but did not align well with potential embodied physics learning because the mechanic could not be directly related to the amount of force imparted. The investigators concluded that the development of a haptic interface for EdGE learning should wait until force-sensitive interfaces are available. Since this research, those interfaces have become available, and have submitted a Cyberlearning EXPloratory proposal (Dec 2015) for research on haptic game-based learning as a direct result of this work.

 

FUN Strand 2: Seed Research: Flow Studies Across Multiple Testbeds

Researchers from EdGE, Northern Illinois University, Rutgers University, and University of Tampere studied flow experiences in game-like environments.  This study was conducted in 4 settings: An EdGE Physics game for high school students; an NIU engineering game for undergraduates; a Kinect math experience for early elementary students in Tampere, Finland; and within Minecraft.edu with middle school students in Finland who are learning English as a Foreign Language. All teams used the Experience Sampling Method (ESM) to measure flow experiences during learner’s interactions in the environment. This research found that players’ flow, or engagement, was related to improved learning, while immersion alone was not. Several conference papers and an article in Computers and Human Behavior (Hamari et al., 2015) are a direct result of this work.

 

FUN Strand 3: International Study of Identity in Games

The US and Finnish teams shared ongoing research on Identity and how it influences game-based learning. Though efforts to combine instruments and data in overlapping projects  did not prove fruitful, primarily because of language issues, the conversations and attention surred on EdGE research that may have otherwise gone dormant. EdGE researchers continued to work with their partners, New Knowledge Organization, to analyze data from their national online survey of 1500 high school youth about game behaviors and dispositions. This research found that science oriented game players are more inclined to like games that are realistic and related to real world situations than non-science oriented players who prefer games that help them escape reality. This has impacted how the investigators approach STEM game design, trying to use narrative and fantasy when possible to capture the non-science oriented participant. The analysis of the Identity paper was completed on the US team (EdGE) and is published in the journal, Computers in Human Behavior.

 

FUN Strand 4: Intellectual Exchange on Elementary Math and Science Games

The FUN teams from University of Jyvaskula and WGBH shared methods and intellectual expertise in the area of educational game evaluation.
